question: That aside, I, we are still uncomfortable with the arrangement.

question: Throw the cigarette out so we can smell. No! You'll stink up the car. Throw it out!

answer: 9:15. The waitress says the Ellis Unit is about fifteen minutes out of town, so we've got like five and half hours. I --

question: First, this isn't a story. It's an interview. We come, I listen, you watch, we go home. Second, there is no 'us' in the assignment.

question: Drive around looking for decent restaurant.
answer: You know, your reputation as Siberian- Female-Dog-Person doesn't do you justice.

question: My reputation got us invited here. I play by the rules. It's called objectivity.
answer: So where do we report?

question: Stemmons. Sorry, won't happen again. I'm Duke Grover, T.D.C. community relations. And these days I always like to ask, now do you prefer Miss, Mrs. or Ms.?

question: Bitsey it is. Margie, I'm stealin' your umbrella. Bitsey, you ever been in a prison?

question: Well, we house 422 inmates here. Average stay with us is nine years. Some get commuted, move on, most get killed. It'll put you off your supper, but then it's supposed to. Afternoon, Earl. We've got three concerns here Rules say seven days prior to execution inmates must be interviewed in a cage. This changes for no man. You're not carryin' a weapon are you?
answer: No.

question: Thank you.
answer: Miss Bloom?

question: Yes.
answer: Did that P.R. man validate your parkin'?

question: He said the gift shop could do it.
answer: She's a smart one. Benjamin Belyeu, Mr. Gale's attorney.

question: This is Zack.
answer: Pleasure. And this is the man of the hour.

question: Now, why can't they turn that thing down?
answer: My lawyer respectfully suggests you adjust the speaker-system volume. They're practicing being cruel and unusual.

question: Mrs. Bloom, I'm sure you're a bitin' at the bit. Now, it is our understanding that you are to have three two-hour sessions. Today, tomorrow and Thursday, all at three in the P.M. I'm sorry we can't afford you more time, but contrary to popular rumor we have not yet begun to fight. Furthermore, it's our understanding that you will do this with no recording equipment of any kind. You have my Gregg book?

question: So...
answer: Sorry. Have a seat.

question: He's a character.
answer: Yeah, known Benny most my life. Met the summer after 4th grade, spent the day burning ants with his dad's magnifying glass. We called it playing 'Execution.' Since I grew up in foster homes, he's become the only family I have.

question: Where's your ex-wife?
answer: We agreed minimal contact would be easier. Please don't mention her, or my son.

question: All right. Anything else, just clearly say, 'off the record.' I'll take it to my grave. But then you know that about me. Otherwise I wouldn't be here. Is this recording equipment?
answer: How should we start?

question: I'd say you're a man with a story to tell, Mr. Gale. You chose the magazine, the format. You chose me. Go.
answer: Think. What do you fantasize about? World peace? Thought so. Money-Fame-Ferrari? A Pulitzer? Nobel? M.T.V. Music Award? A genius hunk -- ostensibly bad but secretly simmering with noble passions, and willing to sleep on the wet spot? A Victoria's Secret model -- just slumming between law school and running her family's Vastly Endowed Foundation for Tragically Sad-Eyed Children? Okay, good, you see Lucan's point. Fantasies must be unrealistic. The minute you get something, you don't, you can't, want it anymore. To exist, desire needs absent objects. So desire supports itself with crazy fantasies... This is what Pascal means when he says the only time we're truly happy is when day-dreaming about future happiness. Or why we say, 'The hunt is sweeter than the kill' or 'Be careful what you wish for.' Not because you'll get it, but because you're doomed not to want it if you do. Think about it next time you're at a wedding.

question: Think. What do you fantasize about? World peace? Thought so. Money-Fame-Ferrari? A Pulitzer? Nobel? M.T.V. Music Award? question: 'Governor, you bat a lovely lash for a woman who executed thirty eight last year.'

question: Anything else?

question: Apropos playing Mother.

question: That's 'cause you're a special-duper- super-quadruper boy. Who's now going to sleep. Who loves you? Ooooh. Good night, son.
answer: Do Cloud Dog.

question: Talking about me?
answer: Yep.

question: He tell you I said when you were circumcised they threw away the wrong part.
answer: He mentioned it. It's called schmuck.

question: What?
answer: The part of the foreskin that gets thrown away. I think it's called schmuck.

question: Black Bush.
answer: You were a jerk this afternoon.

question: For what it's worth, I didn't know about the suspension.
answer: Is that supposed to be an apology?

question: I'm done.
answer: I'm not a student anymore.

question: Don't think I want to know what that means.
answer: There once was woman named Berlin, Who liked a bit now and again. Not now and again, But Now! And Again! And Again! And Again! And Again! Cute, huh?

question: Cute.
answer: I have a secret. But I have to come over there to tell you. Here I come. I wasn't after the grade.

question: Berlin, this, this is not...
answer: Ssshhhh. We'll just talk, analyze, contemplate. Or... you can put your mouth on my body. Don't reject me. Please.

question: Rip them off.
answer: Berlin is back against the sink, undoing David's fly as he takes his T-shirt off. The MUSIC from downstairs seems even LOUDER. His pants and underwear fall. He starts to penetrate her.

question: No. From behind. Yes. Do it hard.

question: Harder. Harder. Yes. Bite me. Bite my shoulder.
answer: Berlin is pulling David into her. They approach a climax. David and Berlin stand still and apart, breathing heavily into the reality-inducing silence. He looks at her in the mirror, a look of shame. She gives him an odd smile.

question: Okay, let's say we find an innocent on death row. Wouldn't matter. Corrections would let him go. Governor Harding would go on TV, say, 'Thanks to the good people at DeathWatch, the system works.' Yeah, if they executed an innocent, and we had absolute, undeniable, in-your-face proof, we could demand abolition. Just like happened in England. Are you okay?
answer: Sorry. Yeah.

question: But it hasn't happened, not since '76. And won't happen. Dead men can't make a case.
answer: And 'Almost Martyrs' don't count.

question: Just keep it rational. The death penalty is expensive and ineffective. No one wants to see a murderer as a victim.
answer: Um-hum.

question: And stop that.
answer: What?

question: Active listening. I hate active listeners. Makes me feel like I'm with a Dale Carnegie grad who cares more about appearing to listen than actually listening. Did you bring the Amnesty fax?
answer: I can listen and appear to listen at the same time. Yeah, no. Damn, I left it home.

question: I have a copy. You want to tell me what's up.
answer: Nothing. Everything. Something profoundly stupid happened last night.

question: I hope you used a condom. Jesus Christ, David. Was she one of yours?
answer: It was Berlin.

answer: Constance, you're not my wife. Thank God.

question: I know you can tell yourself it's a position I aspire to, but believe me, I would rather...

question: Let's go.
answer: Are you okay?

question: Alan, let me say somethin' I always say. And I'm gonna keep on sayin.' And that is I hate killin.' That's why my administration is willing to kill to stop it.

question: It's a nice liberal idea, but like most nice liberal ideas, naive.
answer: It's a quote from you, Governor, from your first state attorney campaign.

question: You've got me, Professor. But let me, in my defense, give you a quote. Winston Churchill
answer: So, basically you feel, to choose another quote, 'society must be cleansed of elements which represent its own death.'

question: Well, yes. I would have to agree. Did I say that, too?
answer: No, ma'am. That was Hitler. Governor, can't we examine the possibility that capital punishment isn't working. That murderers aren't deterred by the law because they have about as much forethought as lemmings. That it's expensive, inequably administered, that... ...that we may even be killing innocents.

question: All righty, Mr. Gale, I'll play your game. Name one. Name one innocent man Texas has put to death in my tenure. One. Name one in the last twenty years. In any state in this country.
answer: Dead men can't make a case.

question: Well, as my daddy used to say Well, you certainly had me on that Hitler quote.
answer: Thank you, Governor.

question: These debates are awfully good for the state, don't you think?
answer: Of course.

question: Your exact words were, 'Just tell me when my ego gets in the way of the work.' Now I'm telling you
answer: Look, I wanted you to do this anyway.

question: You put up precisely two seconds of protest at the thought of a televised debate.

question: It means DeathWatch suffers because you're so anxious to finger authority, to publicly prove that David Gale is so much fucking smarter than the powers that be. Learn to work without an audience. Try squeezing money from the donor list. Have you ever licked one single mail-out envelope?
answer: Look, guys, there's not much more to say -- What, arguing with the Governor is a crime?

question: Berlin had my bite marks, bruises, ripped clothing. My skin was beneath her nails. It didn't look like anything but rape. Two days later she called the D.A., said she wouldn't testify, too drunk to be sure, etc. On the plane home, Sharon read about her husband's rape case being dropped.
answer: Why'd she do it?

question: Finger authority, show she was smarter than the powers that be.
answer: Do you know where I can find her?

answer: Anything written on it?

question: Yeah. It said, 'I'm sorrier than you can know.' See you tomorrow, Ms. Bloom.
answer: Try phone records, a net search.

question: Try phone records, a net search.
answer: Fucking better than watching you work. You think he's telling the truth?

question: Don't ask me that. I don't know. There is no truth, only perspectives.
answer: Can't say that. If you say 'there is no truth,' you're claiming it's true that there is no truth -- it's a logical contradiction.

question: Working on our philosophy merit badge, Zack?
answer: I, on the other hand, think Gale's telling the truth.

question: This you know telepathically?
answer: It's just my perspective.

question: Hi. I'm Bitsey Bloom and this is Zack Stemmons. We --
answer: You want the tour?

question: Uh, yes.
answer: There's a twenty-dollar mandatory donation, apiece. But you get a re- enactment photo packet. It's got five pictures.

question: Okay.
answer: I gotta collect first.

question: Oh, sure.
answer: You gotta sign the book. Doesn't have to be your real name, though. First page says you're here to do research on violent crime. The state requires it for nonprofit shit. Take a re-enactment photo packet. If you guys could share one, it would be really cool. The butt wipes where I do prints kinda jerk my chain. That's me. My boyfriend took it. We also did a video. It's fifty bucks 'cause you can see my tits. There's a version without tits, that's thirty- five.

answer: Not so much anymore. We thought this would be like a busy week -- Gale gettin' the prune juice and all. Prune juice is what death row dudes call the poison, 'cause it gives you the shits. My boyfriend says that's probably when he fucked her. Your muscles tense up when you die -- the sex is better. He used those housewife gloves so he wouldn't leave prints. They found sticky stuff from the tape on them. We ask folks not to touch the exhibit.

question: It was in the case file.

question: Off-the-record?

question: Constance was murdered with what's called the Securitat Method. You're hand-cuffed, forced to swallow the key, taped at the mouth, a bag's sealed over your head and you're left to suffocate. The Securitat did this to Romanians who wouldn't inform or confess. Sometimes the bag was ripped off at the last second, you got a second chance. If not, you die knowing the 'key' to your freedom was inside you the whole time. A cheap-but-effective metonym. Problem is I mentioned the method in an early article. The prosecution never knew.
answer: You're telling me someone's framing you?

question: It's more than that. There was a tripod.
answer: Right, facing her body. Are we on?

question: Not a single print was found on it. Someone brought it, wiped it, left it. Why? It's as if they wanted me to know that somewhere there's a record of what really happened that afternoon. As if they wanted me to die knowing the key to my freedom was... out there.
answer: Maybe you're being paranoid?

question: Ms. Bloom. I'm an anti-death row activist on death row. Doesn't that strike you as odd?

question: You could at least hide the bottle.

answer: So, I wanted to get your feedback on the idea.

question: Spring cleaning. She went up at 18, she's 26 now.

Medievalers wouldn't pray to good Judas for fear of getting bad Judas on the line by mistake. Ergo, they only gave him business when really desperate. That's why. Then they changed his name. Constance? Your mail's blowing.

question: Fine. How's Constance?
answer: Sleeping. Mr. Gale, a leukemia patient's condition is highly susceptible to external stress. While we don't want to totally restrict Constance's life --

answer: Constance's illness requires a degree of regularity.

question: Constance has leukemia?
answer: Acute. She was diagnosed last fall. Have I created a problem?

question: Notta on Berlin, we pick up the money in Houston tonight, overheat light came on twice, and you're about to get a surprise.

question: Too late. This is mostly an Oklahoma caravan. I got stuck behind them on the way in. Execution's not for another 36 hours. It's gonna be a zoo. There's the P.R. guy.
answer: What a life, waiting around for someone to die.

question: Fuck, look.
answer: This is a little too coincidental.

question: 'Cause I couldn't see the license plate.
answer: Forget it. What time is it?

question: 6:05. Why don't you have a watch?
answer: It's a long story. Give me an hour. Zack!

question: What!?
answer: It's open.

question: So? Maybe the maid forgot.
answer: Look!

question: I'll check the bathroom. Clear in here! Don't touch it! Fuck, Bitsey, there could have been prints.
answer: Look.

question: She says no one asked for you. And all the room keys are different. Just she and her husband have masters.
answer: What did you tell her?

question: That you have a jealous boyfriend.
answer: Thanks. How about the V.C.R.?

question: She didn't ask. I think she assumed it had something to do with why he was jealous. I still say we should do this in my room -- this one's a fucking crime scene.
answer: Whoever got in here -- without a key in broad daylight -- was probably smart enough not to leave prints. I have the remote.

question: Maybe they could look for D.N.A. Try three.
answer: They don't look for D.N.A. when someone breaks in to deliver, Zack. Here.

question: You sure you want to see what's on here?
answer: No. Start it. I hope this isn't what I think it is. God, no.

question: Fuck. Is it her?
answer: Turn it up.

question: Belyeu says to bring the tape first thing tomorrow. Also said you were right about not calling the police. Are you gonna be okay? Let's say Gale's right. Some sick- fuck-Agatha Christie-wannabe set him up, arranged like the perfect murder. Why send a magazine journalist proof a few hours before he's won? Doesn't make sense.
answer: No, it's perfect. He knows News Magazine won't give the scoop to the dailies or nightly news, not after having paid for it. Probably guessed we wouldn't call the cops. And, most importantly, knows I'll tell Gale tomorrow.

question: Why does he give a shit?
answer: Zack, what if Harraway's murder was just a means to getting Gale. I mean sending him through hell, a sick cat and mouse game. You kill the one person he has left. Make sure he sits six years on death row for the murder -- a place he's made a public career of loathing. And then just let him die, die knowing everyone will remember him with disgust. You destroy his loved ones, his life's work, his memory -- and you make him watch.

question: That's a lot of hate. You're talking beyond sadism. Then why release it?
answer: If the mouse dies the game's over. Maybe the cat's enjoying himself. Or...

question: Or?
answer: Imagine walking to the chamber knowing this exists.

question: The 'cat' is a fucking psychopath.
answer: Yeah, but smart.

question: Why do they call it check-book journalism if we always pay cash? Woa, woa. Sadist at six o'clock!
answer: Is it the truck?

question: Yep, and doing a lousy job of hiding. He must think we're idiots. You think he's our fucked-up feline?

question: No. Just sitting back there.
answer: Can you see the license?

question: Fine. Oh, and bring in Miss Bloom's original when that's done. Don't blame you for not watching that twice.
answer: I couldn't sleep afterwards.

question: I understand. I generally tell folks I'm no more afraid of the grim reaper than I am of a Presbyterian on Mother's Day. But watching your tape... well. I had to keep tellin' myself 'that's not Constance' just to get through. Unfortunately, others may argue the same.
answer: Yeah, but it's her kitchen, in her house.

question: Currently home to Weirdos Incorporated. Arguably, that tape could have been made by anybody with twenty dollars and a tolerance for vulgarity.
answer: But it will at least get us a postponement?

question: I hope so, Miss Bloom, I certainly hope so. But you've got to remember that there's a machine a runnin'. And come six o'clock tomorrow mornin' that machine wants to be fed. Thank you, Joshua. To add to our troubles, your own credibility may come into question.
answer: Why?

question: You've been fraternizin' with the condemned. In the court's eyes, he's the most likely candidate to have put you onto the tape. He's a persuasive man, you're a out-of-state woman -- it don't look good on paper.
answer: But someone put it in my hotel room.

question: A fact for which we have no evidence. Thank you, Bobbi.
answer: Thanks.

question: Well, let's not start readin' Kafka just yet. Could we find a sympathetic judge. I'll file within the hour. You headin' back over to Ellis?
answer: Yeah.

question: Fine. I'll call over at the motel later and give you an update.
answer: Shit.

question: Did you see the cowboy go in?
answer: He went in Belyeu's building?

question: Into his office. Just saw him.
answer: Fuck!

question: Follow him. Find out who he is, where he lives -- what he --

question: Sorry. Look at me. He's not your man. His name is Dusty Wright, DeathWatch Director before Constance. He's a 'bullhorner,' a zealot who thinks a good demonstration has to end in a riot and arrests. 'Almost martyrs don't mean shit.' They fired him. Constance kept him in the organization, and he loved her for it. The man adored her.

question: He and Benny used to work A.C.L.U. cases together, until Dusty punched a clansman in a federal court. Benny sometimes still gives him work, probably had him follow you.

question: To make sure you honored your agreement, one for which there's no contract.
answer: He would've said something.

question: He's a lawyer, Ms. Bloom.
answer: Maybe Dusty was jealous because you were seeing Constance.

question: I wasn't 'seeing' Constance.
answer: She died... she had your sperm --

question: It's more complicated than that.
answer: All I can feel is envy. Remember those Kubler-Ross stages, the ones the dying go through?

question: Denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance. Where are you?
answer: Denial.

question: Denial's my personal favorite.
answer: The whole idea of there being a process makes me tired. I'm not up to the job of Dying Person. Marveling at blades of grass. Lecturing strangers to relish every moment.

question: Mending bridges.
answer: Mending bridges. Confessing regrets. Uuuggh.

question: No regrets?
answer: Nope. Take that back. I wish I had a child.

question: Me, too.
answer: I'm sorry, David. I guess I just wish I would have risked more. Uumm, also not enough sex. Should have had more sex.

question: How much... how many lovers have you had?
answer: Including college?

question: Including college. Well, it's... not every... yeah, you should have had more sex.
answer: You work hard not to be seen as a sex object. Before long, you're not seen at all.

question: I see you. Want to make it five? Finish the hand?
answer: A pity lay. No thanks.

question: It wouldn't be pity. Are you okay?
answer: Don't worry. It's good. Talk to me. Let me hear your voice.

question: I'm here. Happy. I'm very happy.
answer: Hold me tight.

question: I'm here.
answer: Tight... I'm scared.

question: It's okay. Okay.
answer: Don't stop. Stay in me. Please stay in me.

question: Shhh. I'm staying.
answer: I need to feel you inside.

question: It's okay. I'm inside. I'm not pulling out.
answer: I'm so tired.

question: I know, I know.
answer: Tired of being afraid.

question: Shhh.
answer: Help me.

question: I'm here. It's okay.
answer: Help me. Please. Make it stop.

question: Shhh. I'm here. I'm here.
answer: How do you feel about last night?

question: Rescued. You?
answer: Like I have a reason to get out of bed. Ironic, huh?

question: Let's say they move back from Spain, that I somehow got my one weekend a month. Would it matter? By high school, I'd be his weak spot, the focus of locker room jabs, embarrassed pride. In college there'd be late- night angst I can't stand the idea of being his model of failure. Without him, I drink. To cover the hole. To prove to myself he's better off without me. Sorry, just leaving.
answer: But there has to be someone. Someone with a motive, who knew you both. Someone who visited that morning.

question: If I could answer... we wouldn't be having this conversation. It's why I need you, why I chose you. You have my story, now... 'Go.'
answer: There's not enough time.

question: You'll find time.
answer: You know that's not what I meant. You should have done this earlier.

question: You're not here to save me. You're here to save my son's memory of his father -- that's all I want.
answer: You're going to let them kill you.

question: We live to stop death. Eating, inventing, loving, praying, fighting, killing -- choose a verb. All to stall this evil, Job's 'king of terrors.' But what do we really know about it? Nobody comes back. There's a point, when your mind out-lives its obsessions, when your habits survive your dreams, when your losses... You wonder, maybe death is a gift. All I know is that by this time tomorrow, I'll be better off. What I don't know is why. Goodbye, Bitsey.
answer: Goodbye, David.

question: Denied. Tape went to a federal judge two hours ago. Your videographer friend made contact?
answer: No.

question: What you got was definitely a snippet. Could be he has more previews scheduled. Best stick close to your room.
answer: How's David?

question: Holdin' up. I'm headed back over.
answer: Tell him I'll take care of it, about his son, I mean.

question: Will do. We'll talk later? Watch yourselves.
answer: Mr. Belyeu. Were Dusty and Constance close?

question: Thick as thieves.
answer: has her shoes off, sits on the floor with her back against a bed. She's still watching the tape, tired, exasperated. Zack! Wake up! Get up! Did you throw the towel on the floor?

question: has her shoes off, sits on the floor with her back against a bed. She's still watching the tape, tired, exasperated. Zack! Wake up! Get up! Did you throw the towel on the floor?
answer: What?

question: The towel on my bathroom floor. Did you put it there?
answer: Yeah, I guess. It's a hotel room. What --

question: Do you do that at home?
answer: No. Fuck, Bitsey. I'm sorry, it's not like it's --

question: Get up.
answer: What the fuck's wrong with you?

question: Grab the T.V. I want to check something.
answer: What?

question: We're taking a tour.
answer: Where?

question: Is your boyfriend here?
answer: He ain't exactly my boyfriend anymore.

question: Well is his video camera here?
answer: Yeah.

question: Get it.
answer: I gotta collect first.

question: Zoom in a hair. Put the gloves on a dish rack.
answer: I don't have one.

question: Turn them inside out. Move the tape roll about a foot to the left. And get rid of the handcuffs. Come check this, Zack. Could you... what's your name?
answer: Nico's cool.

question: Nico, lie down on the floor, facing the counter.
answer: We can imagine that part. I'll position her.

question: That's fine. Just straighten her legs. What's this?
answer: Towel or something.

question: Okay, look at this. I noticed this back at the hotel. See? She moves her foot. Why?
answer: Fucking good question.

question: It's another fifteen seconds before she comes to. If she had passed out once, without fresh air she wouldn't come back. There was no head trauma, her blood tested normal --
answer: Jesus, maybe she was faking, hoping he would go away.

question: Or... We've got to bag her.
answer: Woa. Not a good idea.

question: Twenty-two seconds. Thirty seconds.
answer: Fuckin' wicked.

question: Thirty-five... Forty... Forty-five... Fifty.
answer: Maybe she shouldn't...

question: Fifty-five... one minute... five... ten... one-fifteen... Fuck. Twenty... twenty-five... thirty...
answer: This isn't cool.

question: ...thirty-five... Fuck... one-forty... one-forty fi...
answer: Zack!

question: Jesus fucking Christ, Bitsey. You okay? What if I'd've waited? No more fucking experiments, all right? Just tell me what's going on. You okay?
answer: She... she did it herself. She used the gloves to keep fingerprints off the tape and bag. Then she put them back on the dish rack, but upside down and inside out, a housewives' habit. A murderer would have just tossed them aside -- like they were the first time we were here, like you do a towel in a hotel.

question: Maybe, all right, maybe. But why wear these?
answer: They threw me. I forgot you have to have the key to put them on. But she needed them. She knew she would instinctively try to rip the bag off, that at some point automatism would kick in.

question: And she swallowed the key so she couldn't get to it. She made sure there was no way out.
answer: Woa, chill, chill. Why not hang yourself, or take pills. Why take your fucking clothes off? Why make it look like a murder?

question: It's so calculated. She's handcuffed, taped at the mouth. The gloves. The damn tripod.
answer: Why, Bitsey? Why fake your own murder?

question: I don't know.
answer: Motive's like a major issue here.

question: Thanks, Zack.
answer: It doesn't make sense. The woman's a bleeding-heart abolitionist. Why frame an innocent man? Why send Gale to the chair for what looks --

question: What'd you say?
answer: She had to know some innocent fuck would take the fall.

question: Oh my God, Zack, that's it! That's why! To prove it happens. To have absolute proof that the system convicts innocents.
answer: Get the fuck out of here.

question: No, that's how she thought. She lived for DeathWatch. If she's gonna die, why not die for it? That's why the tripod was here. To record proof, undeniable proof, the tape. That's why we got an out-take.
answer: A dead woman put the tape in your room?

question: Of course not. She needed help, someone to keep it, release it. Someone she could trust, someone dedicated to the cause...
answer: Thick as thieves. Hairy.

question: Come on. ...Because of the Berlin thing, Constance knew the police would go straight to Gale. In a way, he's perfect. A high profile alcoholic whose life was shit anyway. But...
answer: She was in love with him.

question: I don't know. Something. They were close. She wouldn't want him dead. Remember this thing about Dusty being a bull-horner, going to far?
answer: Why he was fired from DeathWatch, and the A.C.L.U.

question: Right. Maybe the plan was for Dusty to release the tape after Gale's conviction, after a year or so. You know, force him to dry out, let him play the heroic victim, give him back his dignity. So, Dusty Wright's sitting on this tape, waiting, the only one who knows about it. And maybe good ole Dusty starts to think that an erroneous execution is a hell of a lot more politically useful than a last-minute save.
answer: Which would only prove the system works.

question: Yeah. Almost martyrs don't count. What's one murder to stop thousands?
answer: So he'll wait, release the whole tape after the execution.

question: Don't move from the booth. Call the second you see the truck. Remember, let it ring just once. Then get into the woods --
answer: I know. Go.

question: Into the woods, Zack.
answer: Go!

question: Shit!
answer: Zack paces in front of the booth, checks his watch.

question: Shit!
answer: Zack sees lights coming toward him. Gets into the phone booth, drops two coins, dials six numbers. He hesitates to punch the seventh, checks the road. The approaching lights belong to a car. He quickly hangs up.

question: Shit!
answer: Zack hugs himself in the waning drizzle.
